verses.verse: A certain man named Ananias along with his wife, Sapphire, sold some property
but kept some of the money; his wife also know about this. He brought part of it and laid it at the apostles' feet.
Peter said, "Ananias, why has Satan filled your heart to lie to the Holy Spirit to keep some of the money from the land?
"While it remained [with you], wasn't it your own, and after it was sold, wasn't it in your own power? Why have you thought this up in your heart? You haven't lied to men but to God.
[When] Ananias heard those words, he fell down and gave up his spirit. Great fear came on all those who heard these things.
Then the young men got up, wound him up [in burial clothes], carried him out, and buried him.
It was about three hours later when his wife, not knowing what had happened, came in.
Peter started to talk to her, "Tell me whether you sold the land for this much?" She said, "Yes, for that much."

Then Peter said to her, "How is it that you have agreed together to put the Spirit of the Lord to the test? Look see the feet of those who have buried your husband are at the door and will carry you out."
Then she immediately fell down [dead] at his feet and gave up her soul, then the young men came in and found her dead. Then carrying her out, they buried [her] by her husband.
Great fear came on all the church and on as many as heard about these things.
Through the hands of the apostles many signs and wonders happened among the people, and they all were in agreement at Solomon's porch.
Concerning the others, no one dared join with them, but the people thought well of them.
More believers were added to the Lord, multitudes of both men and women.
Therefore they brought the sick into the streets and laid [them] on cots and mats, so that at least the shadow of Peter passing by might cast a shadow on some of them.
There also came a large crowd out of the cities around Jerusalem bringing sick people and those vexed by unclean spirits, and every one of them was healed.
Then the high priest stood up and all those who were with him--those of the sect of the Sadducees--and were full of wrath.
They arrested the apostles and put them in the common prison,
but the Lord's angel opened the prison doors at night and brought them out. He said to them,
"Go, stand, and speak in the temple to all the people all the words of this life."

So when they heard that, they went into the temple in the early morning and taught. Meanwhile the high priest and those with him came and called the council together with the Sanhedrin of the children of Israel. They sent to the prison to have them brought [to them].
But when the officers came and didn't find them in the prison, they returned and told [them],
saying, "Truly we found the prison secured and the guards standing outside the door, but when we opened it up, we found no one in there."
Now when the high priest, the temple captain, and the chief priests heard these things, they were perplexed about it wondering what this would grow into.
Then someone came and told them, saying, "Look, the men whom you put in prison are standing in the temple teaching the people.
So the captain and the officers went and brought them without violence, for they feared the people, lest they would be stoned [to death].
After they had brought them, the set [them] in front of the council, then the high priest asked them, saying,
"Didn't we straightly command you not to teach in this name? Now look you have filled Jerusalem with your teaching and intend to bring this man's blood on us."
Then Peter and the other apostles answered and said, "We must obey God, rather than men.
"The God of our forefathers raised up Jesus whom you killed and hanged on a tree.
"God has exalted him with his right hand [to be] a Prince and a Savior, to give repentance to Israel and forgiveness of sins.
"We are his witnesses of these things, and [so is] the Holy Spirit whom God has given to those who obey him."
When they heard this, they became enraged and took counsel to kill them.
Then one of the council, a Pharisee named Gamaliel, a doctor of the law, stood up. He was very honored among all the people and commanded to put the apostles out for a little while.
He said to them, "You men of Israel, be very careful for yourselves in what you intend to do about these men,

for before these days Theudas rose up bragging to be a somebody with whom a number of men--about 400--joined themselves. These were killed and all those who obeyed him were scattered and brought to nothing.
"After him Judas of Galilee, rose up in the days of taxing and drew away many people after him. He also perished and all those who obeyed him were scattered.
"So now I say to you, Â«Keep away from these men and leave them alone, for if this counsel or this work is from men it will come to nothing,
but if it is from God, you cannot overthrow it, for fear that you will be found to fight against God."
They agreed with him, and when they had called the apostles and beaten them, they commanded that they should not speak in the name of Jesus, then let them go.
They left from the council's presence, rejoicing that they were considered worthy to suffer shame for his name.
Daily in the temple and in every house, they did not stop teaching and preaching Jesus Christ.
